intro: Trophaeum floribundum, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves and a branching stem. It thrives in well-drained soil and partial to full sunlight, making it a popular choice for garden cultivation. Its ornamental value is enhanced by its vibrant color and ease of care.
